The nerves which give rise to the kinesthetic sense
are embedded in the muscle fibers.  I have not heard
of any nerves in the joints that directly sense joint
rotation, although they might exist.  So it seems that
the kinesthetic sense involves neural processing of
the raw muscle contraction data, the result being
knowledge of where the body parts are.  I suppose we
don't know if that processing is wired in, or is
learned.  I suspect it is mostly wired in.


=====
Mitchell Timin
